thread.title: Jared Poche threw the first LSU no-hitter in 38 years after
thread.title_full: Jared Poche threw the first LSU no-hitter in 38 years after

author: rivals.com
title: Jared Poche threw the first LSU no-hitter in 38 years after
text:
Jared Poche threw the first LSU no-hitter in 38 years after Alex Lange tossed five shutout innings as the Tigers opened the season by sweeping Army 9-0 and 6-0 at The Box on Saturday afternoon.
GAME 1
HOW THEY SCORED
LSU first inning – Cole Freeman singled and stole second base. Freeman advanced to third on a throwing error by catcher Jon Rosoff. Freeman scored on Antoine Duplantis’ ground out to the first baseman. Kramer Robertson walked. Greg Deichmann hit a two-run homer over the centerfield fence. LSU 3, ARMY 0
LSU fourth inning – Jake Slaughter hit a leadoff home run over the leftfield fence. LSU 4, ARMY 0
LSU fifth inning – Brennan Breaux singled and scored on a double by Freeman. After Duplantis flied out to the rightfielder, Robertson walked. Robertson was safe at second and moved to third on a throwing error by the first baseman Tyler Giovinco on Deichmann’s ground ball. Freeman scored on the play. Slaughter was hit by a pitch to load the bases. Robertson scored on a single by Bryce Adams. Deichmann scored on a bases-loaded walk to Josh Smith. Slaughter scored on a sacrifice fly to the leftfielder by pinch-hitter Nick Coomes. LSU 9, ARMY 0
KEY STRETCH OF GAME
With Lange pitching, the Tigers did not need much offensive support. LSU jumped to a 3-0 lead in the first inning – two coming on Deichmann’s home run.
KEY TEAM STATISTICS
The Tigers only had six hits – one more than Army. . .The Cadets made three errors, while LSU did not commit a miscue. The Tigers recorded two double plays. . .LSU stranded just four runners – two in scoring position. . .Army was 1-for-8 with runners in scoring position.
INDIVIDUAL STAT LEADERS
LSU
Cole Freeman: 2-for-3, 2 runs scored, 1 RBI, 1 double, 1 stolen base
Greg Deichmann: 1-for-4, 3 RBIs, 2 runs scored, 1 home run
Jake Slaughter: 1-for-1, 2 runs scored, 1 home run, 1 RBI
Kramer Robertson: 0-for-1, 2 runs scored
Alex Lange: 5 innings, 4 hits, 6 strikeouts
ARMY
John McCarthy: 2-for-3
Matt Ball: 4.1 innings, 5 hits, 7 runs, 6 earned runs, 4 walks, 1 strikeout
AP Photo/Gerald Herbert GAME 2
HOW THEY SCORED
LSU fifth inning – Adams doubled and moved to third on a single by Michael Papierski. Adams scored on a sacrifice fly to the centerfielder by Smith. Freeman was awarded first base when his line drive hit second base umpire Chris Symons. Papierski was forced at third base on Duplantis’ ground ball to the shortstop. Freeman and Duplantis scored on a triple by Robertson. LSU 3, ARMY 0
LSU sixth inning – Slaughter singled and advanced to third on a double by Beau Jordan. After Adams was hit by a pitch, Slaughter scored on a wild pitch by Logan Smith. After Papierski grounded out to the shortstop, Jordan scored on an infield single by Smith. Pinch-runner Zach Watson scored on an infield single by Freeman. LSU 6, ARMY 0
KEY STRETCH OF GAME
Even though Poche was nearly perfect, LSU was in a scoreless game in the middle of the fifth. The Tigers pushed across three runs in the fifth. Adams started the inning with a double. He eventually scored on a sacrifice fly by Smith. Robertson capped the inning with a two-run triple.
KEY TEAM STATISTICS
LSU had 11 hits with every starter but Duplantis collecting one. . .The only Tigers error was a missed fly ball by Deichmann in rightfield. . .LSU was 0-for-3 with runners in scoring position in the first four innings. The Tigers were 4-for-8 with runners in scoring position in the next two innings.
INDIVIDUAL STAT LEADERS
LSU
Kramer Robertson: 2-for-3, 2 RBIs, 1 triple
Josh Smith: 2-for-2, 2 RBIs
Cole Freeman: 2-for-4, 1 RBI, 1 run scored
Jared Poche: 7 innings, 4 strikeouts
ARMY
Tyler Giovingo: 5 innings, 9 hits, 6 runs, 6 earned runs, 1 walk
LSU’S PLAYER OF THE DAY
Poche was only the sixth pitcher in LSU history to throw a no-hitter. The no-hitter was the first for a Tigers hurler in 38 years. Bobby Landry threw a no-hitter against USM in 1979. Five of the six no-hitters came in seven-inning games. Fred Southerland had the nine-inning no-hitter against Tulane in 1962. Poche struck out four – all in the first two innings. He was supported by some outstanding defense – particularly by Robertson at shortstop. The only Army base-runner was Josh White who reached when Deichmann missed his shallow fly ball in the fourth inning. The victory was the 28th of Poche’s career. He is one victory shy of reaching the top ten list for LSU pitchers.
Poche’s comments: “I still can’t believe it happened. My dad said (Friday) that I was going to throw a no-hitter. I said ‘why did you say that. I will probably get hit all around the park.’ Then (no-hitter) happened. I wasn’t thinking about the no-hitter until the fifth inning because the score was 0-0. Then, we got some runs. I went out there today and filled up the zone. I let my defense make the plays. None of this would have been possible without the plays made by Kramer, Cole and Josh.”
NOTES
There was one change in LSU’s starting lineup for the first game. Breaux replaced Beau Jordan in leftfield. Army started a righthanded pitcher in the first game, so the lefthanded-hitting Breaux was in the lineup. Breaux batted ninth in the lineup. Slaughter hit fifth in the batting order – the spot supposed to be occupied by Jordan, who was in leftfield in the second game. . .Four players had hits in both games of the doubleheader – Freeman (4-for-7), Slaughter (2-for-4), Adams (2-for-5) and Deichmann (2-for-6). . .Caleb Gilbert and Austin Bain each threw a shutout inning in the opener. . .The last time the Tigers won both games of a doubleheader by a shutout was 1986 when they swept Mississippi State 4-0 and 4-0 at Starkville. . .The last time LSU won its first two games of a season by a shutout was 1996 when it beat Western Kentucky 9-0 and 18-0. . .The last time the Tigers began the season with a doubleheader was 2001 against Kansas State at The Box. LSU and the Wildcats split the doubleheader. The Tigers won their first two games for the 16th straight year. In 2001, LSU lost its season-opener to Kansas State (9-8). . . Army is 0-3 for the season. . .Eric Walker will be the starting pitcher for the Tigers in the game against Air Force on Sunday afternoon. . .The paid attendance for the first game was 10,834. The actual crowd for the first game was about 5,400. . .The paid attendance for the second game was 11,174. The actual crowd for the second game was about 7,400.
FROM THE LOCKER ROOM
Coach Paul Mainieri’s comments: “Jared seemed pretty determined, particularly at the end of the game. He was like he was against Rice in the regional last year when he came out of the bullpen. The defense by Kramer Robertson was unbelievable. It was a real team effort. We got some good clutch hitting late in the second game, some good two-strike hitting. You are worried in a seven-inning game. One bad break can turn the tide. We got some great pitching today from Poche and Alex Lange.”
UP NEXT
LSU will play host to Air Force at The Box on Sunday. First pitch is scheduled for 1 p.m. Central. The Falcons (2-1) split a doubleheader against Tulane in New Orleans on Saturday. Air Force lost the first game 4-3 and won the second game 3-2. The LSU-Air Force game will be available on the SEC Digital Network.
Edit
